column35: Patrick Ekezie Egbule is a Professor of Vocational and Workforce Education  and has been in active and engaged teacher-scholar at Delta State University  Abraka  Nigeria since 1994. He obtained his Ph.D in Agricultural Education from the University of Nigeria  Nsukka in 1995  a Post-Doctoral Masters degree in Industrial and Labour Relations in 2003  and was promoted to a full Professor in 2007. He has published widely in both national and international journals and currently the editor/reviewer of renowned journal such as the Nigeria Vocational Association Journal (NVAJ) and the Association of Agricultural Educatorâ€™s Association of Nigeria Journal (AEANJ). He is the author of several books including Fundamentals and Practice of Agricultural Education; and Entrepreneurship in Theory and Practice. He has served as Chairman/Member of several course accreditation teams for the National Universities Commission (NUC)  and consultant to Senate of the Federal Republic of Nigeria on Agriculture and Rural Development. He served as President  Nigeria Vocational Association (NVA)  now Association of Vocational and Technical Educators of Nigeria (AVTEN) between 2012 and 2017.

column35: OKEBUKOLA  Peter Akinsola is a Distinguished Professor of science and computer education at Lagos State University. He holds a PhD from the University of Ibadan (1984) followed by specialised training at M.I.T and Harvard. He was Executive Secretary  NUC (2001-2006). His eight Fellowships include: Fellow of the Science Association of Nigeria (FSAN) and Fellow of the International Academy of Education (FIAE). He won the prestigious 1992 UNESCO Prize for the Communication of Science. With over 150 international publications  his current research is on elearning and quality assurance in higher education. column35: Adetayo Erlinda is a Professor of Entrepreneurship in the Faculty of Administration  Obafemi Awolowo University  Ife. She holds a Ph.D. in Business Administration from Obafemi Awolowo University  Ife. She was the Vice Dean of the Faculty of Administration (2016-2018) and during her Sabbatical (2014-2015)  she was the Head of Department (Business Administration)  Bowen University  Iwo.  She is a Fellow of National Institute of Marketing of Nigeria (NIMN)  Chartered Institute of Commerce of Nigeria (CICN)  and Institute of Personnel   Administration of Nigeria (IPAN); and a Member of International Council for Small Business (ICSB). She delivered her inaugural lecture titled: Entrepreneurship Education: A Panacea to Graduate Unemployment? She can be reached via her email erlinda77adetayo@yahoo.com and mobile phone number 08067708453.

column35: Professor Emmanuel Maximin-Agha is a Jidokwan Taekwondo 9th Dan & Higher Grand Master. He is a Professor of Exercise Physiology in the Department of Human Kinetics and Health Education  at Ebonyi State University  Abakliki. He was born in Lagos  Nigeria  and attended the Nigerian Defence Academy  Kaduna (29th Regular Combatant course)  after which he was commissioned  into the Nigerian Army Intelligence Corps  and the University of Ibadan  where he obtained his PhD. Professor Maximin-Agha has authored several books and his current research interest shows him to be a strong advocate of a paradgm shift from man as a biochemical being to man as an energetic and informational being with sophisticated  high speed communications systems mediating a complex information flow within our bodies.

column28: Environmental Geochemistry and Health (Medical Geology) - Environmental Management
column29: My core area of research involves integration of geology and environmental sciences in terms of pollution studies  assessment and monitoring with respect to hydrocarbon (THS & PAHs)  essential elements (iodine  selenium etc.)  potentially toxic metals (As Pb Cd  Cr etc.) using geological (i.e rocks  soils  sediments and water) and environmental samples (i.e urine and blood).I have worked extensively on environmental geochemistry of radionuclides of rocks and soils from abandoned and quarry sites; analysis of hydrocarbon wastes ( oilfield brine  geological cuttings and muds)  domestic and industrial waste; Urban and Rural assessment using geochemical approach and environmental geochemistry of pedological materials.

column35: Adagbonyin Asomwan Sonnie is a Professor of English in the Faculty of Arts  Ambrose Alli University  Ekpoma  Edo State  Nigeria. He holds a Ph.D. from the University of Benin (2000). He was Sub-Dean  Faculty of Arts (2001 -2002)  Ag. Head of English (2002 - 2004)  Director  General Studies (2005 - 2007); (2016 till date) and Director  Academic Planning (2008). He is a Fellow of the Institute of Industrial Administration. His current research is Cognitive Stylistics. He has successfully supervised 3 Ph.Ds. His email address is asomwan@aauekpoma.edu.ng. His telephone number is +2348035601770.

column35: Ogunrin Olubunmi is a Professor of Internal Medicine/Neurology in the School of Medicine  College of Medical Sciences  University of Benin  Benin City. He is a Fellow of West African (1997) and Royal College of Physicians (2014)  Royal Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene (2007) and African Scientific Institute. column35: I am Christopher Ebeagbor Ukhun  a Professor of Philosophy  Department of Philosophy  Ambrose Alli University  Ekpoma. I hold a B.A (Hons) and M.A Philosophy  University of Ibandan and Ph.D at Edo State University (now Ambrose Alli University)  Ekpoma. Certificate in Entrepreneurship Skill Development  Paris Junior College  Texas  U.S.A.  A two time Head of Department and Dean  Faculty of Arts  Ambrose Alli University  Ekpoma.   An External-Examiner to State  Private and Federal Universities.  The vision and mission statement of my University was written by me and three others.  I am a resource person to the United Nations (UN) Abuja on Gender issues.

column35: OlURISHE  Temidayo is a Professor of Pharmacology in the Faculty of Pharmaceutical Sciences  AHmadu Bello University  Zaria. He holds a PhD from the Ahmadu Bello University  (2010). He belongs to several professional bodies including the British Pharmacological Society and the  West African Society for Pharmacology. He is currently working on the chronotoxicological evaluation of some antibitics and anti tumor drug combinations as well as those of some common herbal remedies.His emphasis is on hepatorenal toxicity. His email address is olurishe@hotmail.com. He can be reached on +2348036005775

column35: ADERIYE  Jadesola Babatunde Idowu is a Professor of Microbiology in the Faculty of Science  Ekiti State University  Ado-Ekiti. He holds a Ph.D. degree from the University of Ife (now Obafemi Awolowo University)  Ile-Ife. He was Head of Department (1990-1994; 2014-2016)  Director  PreDegree Science Programme (1995-1998)  Director  Centre for Research and  Development  (2000-2005)  and Deputy Vice Chancellor of Lead City University  Ibadan (March to June  2011). column33: ï€  Providing Leadership in Nigerian University Education Research Enterprise: The Imperative of Research Ethics Abstractâ€”It is universally acknowledged that the primary function of universities is the generation and dissemination of knowledge. This mission is pursued through the research component of the university programme especially at the post-graduate level. The senior academic staff teach  supervise and provide general academic leadership to post-graduate students who are expected to carry out research leading to the presentation of dissertation as requirement for the award of doctoral degree in their various disciplines. Carrying out the research enterprises involves a lot of corroboration among individuals and communities. The need to safeguard the interest of everyone involved in the enterprise makes the development of ethical standard in research imperative. Ensuring the development and effective application of such ethical standard falls within the leadership role of the vice â€“chancellors  Deans of post-graduate schools/ faculties  Heads of Departments and supervisors. It is the relevance and application of such ethical standard in Nigerian university research efforts that this study discussed. The study adopted the descriptive research design. A researcher-made 4 point rating scale was used to elicit information from the post-graduate dissertation supervisors sampled from one university each from the six geo-political zones in Nigeria using the purposive sampling technique. The data collected was analysed using the mean score and standard deviation. The findings of the study include among others that there are several cases of unethical practices by Ph.D dissertation students in Nigerian universities. Prominent among these include duplicating research topics  making unauthorized copies of data paper or computer programme  failing to acknowledge contributions of relevant people and authors  rigging an experiment to prempt the result among others. Some of the causes of the unethical practices according to the respondents include inadequate funding of universities resulting in inadequate remuneration for university teachers  inadequacy of equipment and infrastructures  poor supervision of Ph.D students â€™ poverty on the side of the student researchers and non-application of sanctions on violators. Improved funding of the Nigerian universities system with emphasis on both staff and student research efforts  admitting academic oriented students into the Ph.D programme and ensuring the application of appropriate sanctions in cases of unethical conduct in research featured prominently in the needed leadership imperatives. Based on the findings of the study  the researchers recommend the development of university research policies that is closely tied to each universityâ€™s strategic plan. Such plan should define the research focus that will attract more funding and direct students interest towards it without violating the principle of academic freedom. The plan should also incorporate the establishment of a research administration office to provide the necessary link between the students and funding agencies and also organise training for supervisors on leadership activities expected of them while educating students on the processes involved in carrying out a qualitative and acceptable research study. Such training should include the ethical principles and guidelines that encompass all parts of research from research topic through the literature review to the design and the truthful reporting of results  Keywordsâ€”Academic leadership  ethical standards  research stakeholders  research enterprise.  I.	INTRODUCTION I t is a normal occurrence for individuals  communities  and nations to experience one problem situation or another. At such times  varieties of ways are employed to find solutions to the problem(s). Globally  universities are established as research centres to find solutions to societiesâ€™ problems through the application of the rational mind to obtaining empirical data and processing them before drawing conclusions on whether the problem(s) have been solved or not [1].  	Research activities normally begin from the inception of a university by the academic staff in the various disciplines and extend significantly to students as the establishment of Postgraduate Studies. Postgraduate students in Nigerian universities are expected to carry out researches leading to the presentation of a thesis or dissertation as requirement for the award of the Masters Degree or Doctor of Philosophy (Ph.D) Degree. 	Presently  Nigerian universities have produced a very significant numbers of Ph.D and masters graduates virtually in all disciplines without commensuration of contributions to national development research-wise. This is evident by the lack of research dividends accruing from Nigerian universities and lack of impact of research results on pressing socio-economic problems. 	The question arising from this report is therefore why is Nigerian universitiesâ€™ Postgraduate research not making any commendable impact on national development socially and economically? A number of factors have been identified as answer to the above question. They include lack of research focus  the preponderance of theoretical rather than applied research  lack of research and development in public and private sector enterprises  poor and inadequate funding. There is however an important factor that scholars  researchers  and stakeholders seem to overlook  the research ethical demands. It is this ethical dimension of research practice in Nigerian universities that this study focused on with particular reference to Postgraduate Studentsâ€™ Research. Literature Review 	Universities are established essentially to lead the search for knowledge. This major objective of universities can only be achieved through cutting edge research since it is the only means of producing knowledge [2]. Generally  the orientation of university research is geared towards finding solutions to societal problems in all areas; educationally  political  social  environmentally  economically and even spiritually. The quality of research input received from universities is a major determinant of the quality of life in any society. The research component of the university programme is pursued through academic staff research efforts and principally through Postgraduate research dimension. Carrying out the research enterprises involves a lot of corroboration among individuals and communities. The need to safeguard the interest of all stakeholders (researchers and participants) in the research enterprise resulted in the development of research ethics. According to Babarabe [3] there were no clear regulations in the conduct of research activities prior to the end of the Second World War in 1945. This led to several abuses by some scientists working on new weapon systems resulting in their committing many atrocities. The trial of some of the perpetrators of the atrocities and the charges brought against them in the Nuremberg Doctorsâ€™ trials of 1946-1947 paved the way for the emergence of first set of rules to guide the conduct of research [4]. The Nuremberg code was followed by the Helsinki Declaration of the World Medical Association of 1964 with its 7 basic principles. This was followed by the Belmont Report of 1979 from the National Commission for the Protection of Human subjects of Biomedical and Behavioural Research with its 4 basic principles.  	All the ethical guidelines according to Minnesota University [5] emphasize the need for the application of ethical behavior in research to all stages and aspects of the investigation from the planning stage to the execution and reporting stages including drawing conclusions and making recommendations. Generally  Resnik [6] summarized the ethical principles addressed by various codes as follows: honesty  objectivity  integrity  carefulness  openness  respect for intellectual property  confidentiality  responsible publication  responsible monitoring  respect for colleagues  social responsibility  non-discrimination  competence  legality  animal care and human subject protection.  	Similarly  the American Psychological Association identified five principles of research ethics which are commonly emphasized in Nigerian universities especially in the Faculties of Education. They include: discussing intellectual property frankly  being conscious of multiple roles  following informed consent rules  respecting confidentiality and privacy and tapping into ethics resources by ensuring that the rights of research subjects are protected and their voluntary participation acknowledged.  	Non-observance of the ethical standards at any stage of research amount to unethical practice which could invalidate the reported findings and render it false and misleading to other researchers and the public. Some unethical practices as identified by Resnik [7] include: using an inappropriate statistical technique in order to enhance the significance of the research.  â€¢	Conducting a review of the literature that fails to acknowledge the contributions of other people in the field or relevant prior work. â€¢	Not reporting an adverse event in a human research experiment.  â€¢	Rigging an experiment you know how it will turn out.  â€¢	Trimming authors from a date set without discussing the reasons in the page. â€¢	Assigning values to no responses in a questionnaire. â€¢	Making unauthorized copies of date  paper or computer programme. â€¢	Sabotaging someoneâ€™s work.  The damaging consequences of unethical practices in the research enterprises demands that universities as research based institutions should vigorously pursue the ideals of research ethics and institutionalize it so as to make their research endeavours worthwhile in meeting the needs and challenges of their society and the global society. It is the relevance and application of such ethical standard in Nigeria university research that this study discussed.  Methodology 	The study adopted the descriptive research design. A researcher-made 4-point Likert type rating scale was used to collect data from 120 Ph.D dissertation supervisors sampled from one university each from the six geo-political zones in Nigeria using the purposive sampling technique. The data collected was analyzed using the mean score and standard deviation.  Results Analysis Research Question One  Some unethical practices among Ph.D. Dissertation researchers Table 1: Item by Item mean ratings of supervisors on some unethical practices among Ph.D. Dissertation researchers.  S/N	Item Statement: 	Supervisorsâ€™ 		 N	_ X	 SD	 Decision 1	Using an inappropriate statistical technique 	120	2.79	0.81	Agreed 2	Failure to acknowledge the contributions of relevant people in the study.	120	2.82	0.91	Agreed 3	Duplicating research topic.	120	2.88	0.67	Agreed 4	Failure to keep good relevant research.	120	2.43	1.09	Disagreed 5	Failure to maintain research date and reasonable period of time.	120	2.17	1.01	Disagreed 6	Obtaining good grades through corruption.	120	2.22	1.07	Disagreed 7	Not reporting an adverse event in a human research experiment.	120	2.84	0.78	Agreed 8	Rigging an experiment to preempt the research.	120	2.69	0.77	Agreed 9	Making unauthorized copies of the paper or computer programme.	120	2.91	0.79	Agreed 10	Collecting data from a sample not in the topic.	120	2.22	0.84	Disagreed 11	Using instrument that did not meet the reliability specifications. 	120	2.25	0.89	Disagreed 	Mean of Means		2.57		  	Table 1 above shows the item by Item mean ratings of supervisors on some unethical practices among Ph.D. Dissertation researchers. It was indicated in the table using mean scores that items 1  2  3  7  8 and 9 were agreed by the supervisors having recorded a mean score above the criterion mean of 2.50. The table also indicated that items; 4  5  6  10 and 11 recorded mean scores below the criterion mean of 2.50 and were considered as disagreed. The mean of means stood at 2.57. The conclusion is that some unethical practices among Ph.D. Dissertation researchers include duplicating research topics  making unauthorized copies of data  paper or computer programme  failing to acknowledge contributions of relevant people and authors  using inappropriate instrument and statistical technique  rigging an experiment to preempt the result  failure to report contradicting or adverse findings and using false sample. Research Question Two Some Causes of Unethical Practices Table 2: Item by Item mean ratings of supervisors on Some Causes of Unethical Practices.  S/N	Item Statement: 	Supervisorsâ€™ 		 N	_ X	 SD	 Decision 12	Inadequate funding	120	3.08	0.87	Agreed 13	Inadequate equipment.	120	2.87	0.99	Agreed 14	Infrastructural problems.	120	2.96	0.87	Agreed 15	Poor post graduate supervision and supervisors. 	120	2.32	0.82	Disagreed 16	Lack of current journals.	120	2.22	0.78	Disagreed 17	Inadequate remuneration for university lecturers.	120	2.19	0.93	Disagreed 18	Poverty on the side of researchers. 	120	2.11	0.85	Disagreed 19	Non-application of sanctions.	120	2.76	0.79	Agreed 	Mean of Means		2.56		  	Table 2 shows the item by Item mean ratings of supervisors on some causes of unethical practices. A look at the table indicated that items 12  13  14 and 19 were seen as agreed by most of the respondents (supervisors) since their item mean scores were above the criterion mean of 2.50  while other items (15  16  17 and 18) had mean scores below the criterion mean of 2.50 and were considered as disagreed. The mean of means for table 2 is 2.56. The conclusion of this table is that inadequate funding  inadequate equipment  infrastructural problems and non-application of sanctions are some causes of unethical practices. Research Question Three Suggestions on Leadership Imperative Table 3: Item by Item mean ratings of supervisors on Suggestions on Leadership Imperative S/N	Item Statement: 	Supervisorsâ€™ 		 N	_ X	 SD	 Decision 20	Improved funding of the university system.	120	2.67	0.81	Agreed 21	Providing training opportunities for researchers in research ethics.	120	2.87	0.69	Agreed 22	Ensuring the competency of interest.	120	2.61	0.66	Agreed 23	Ensuring that appropriate sanction in cases of unethical conduct in research ensuring that only academic applicants are admitted into Ph.D. programme.	120	2.86	0.59	Agreed 24	Over researched topics should not be approved for Ph.D. dissertation.	120	2.87	0.94	Agreed 25	The remuneration for Ph.D. dissertation should be improved upon.	120	2.76	0.91	Agreed 26	Supervisors should refer their students to experts in areas of specializations. 	120	2.69	0.81	Agreed 	Mean of Means		2.76		  	Table 3 shows the item by Item mean ratings of supervisors on Suggestions of Leadership Imperative. The results indicated that all the items (20-26) were held as agreed having mean scores that fall above the criterion mean of 2.50. The mean of means score of 2.76 was recorded for the items.  Discussion of Findings 	Analysis of data on the unethical practices among Ph.D student researchers indicate the most prevalent unethical practices to include: duplicating research topics  making unauthorized copies of data  paper or computer programme  failing to acknowledge contributions of relevant people and authors  using inappropriate instrument and statistical technique  rigging an experiment to preempt the result  failure to report contradicting or adverse findings and using false sample.  	The prevalence of such magnitude of unethical practices by Nigerian University Doctorate Students raises doubt on the validity of findings from some of the researches. This goes on to explain Mustpha [8] worry on the lack of research dividends accruing from Nigerian universities and lack of impact of research results on pressing socio-economic problems as constantly deplored by policymakers. Also  the occurrence of unethical practice in research on a large scale as reported in this study as in the case of plagiarism in form of mass copying of data  literature or computer programme  failing to acknowledge contributions of relevant people can result to personal and national economic losses.  	Data on the causes of the unethical practices found among Doctorate Students in Nigerian Universities show that inadequate funding of universities is a major factor because of its multiplying chain effect in contributing to inadequate remuneration for university teachers who are in most cases are made to exceed the approved student ratio for such supervision because of inadequate number of required teachers. This in most cases result to poor supervision of Ph.D students. Also linked to inadequate funding is adequate equipment  materials and infrastructures needed for quality research work. Quality research rests on the availability of the right facilities and the right environment. This seems not to be the case in most Nigerian universities where the required cost of up-to-date information  techniques and technology according to Manguwat [9] may be regarded as unreasonably large amounts of money. It is however important to observe that the funding challenges facing Nigerian universities is not peculiar to Nigeria but has assumed a global dimension. Clark [10] described universities in Europe as having entered in the age of turmoil for which there is no end in sight. According to him  â€œthe disjuncture is rooted in a simple fact: demands on universities outrun their capacity to respondâ€. 	Closely connected to the paucity of funds plaguing the Nigerian university system is the problem of poverty facing the student researchers. This agrees with Balarabe [11] submission that the high rate of copyright violations through the illegal photocopying of textual materials and copying of computer software including inability to embark on data collection are attributable to poverty/financial constraints on the side of the student researchers. Another important student factor identified is the admission of non-academic students into the Ph.D programme. Also indentified as one of the major causes of unethical practices in Ph.D student research endeavour is non-application of sanctions on violators.  	Manguwat [12] attributed this problem to many students pursuing Postgraduate Studies with wrong motive of using it to wage war against unemployment and not necessarily because they are interested or have the intellectual capability to pursue such programmes. They end up in every form of academic fraud. Failure to apply sanctions to serve as deterrent to involving in unethical conduct widespread and attractive to the researchers.  	The leadership imperatives expected of stakeholders (Vice Chancellors  Deans of School of Post-Graduate/Faculties  Head of Departments  and Supervisors) in university research enterprise based on the findings of this study include improved funding of the universities by their proprietors and university administrators by boosting the internally generated revenue machinery and ensuring curbing wastage within the system through effective utilization of resources and application of prudency in financial matters. Such well-managed universities with enhanced reputation will attract research grant which will serve as not only a source of help to the staff and students but also accrue to the university as administrative costs. Such grant will help the academic but poor student to avoid poverty-related unethical practice in research.  â€¢	ensuring the admission of academic-oriented students into the Postgraduate programme especially at the Doctoral level through well-organized aptitude tests and screening. â€¢	applying appropriate and adequate sanction in cases of unethical practice in conducting research enterprise through a well-articulated research ethics committee made up of reputable senior staff members.  Finally  the researchers recommend the development and adoption of university research policy in Nigeria that is closely tied to each universityâ€™s strategic plan as advocated by Makanjuola [13] Such plan should define the research focus that will attract meaningful attention and more funding and direct students to it without violating the principle of academic freedom. The plan should also incorporate the establishment of a research administrative office to provide the necessary link between the students and funding agencies and also organize training for supervisors on leadership activities expected of them while educating students on the processes involved in carrying out a qualitative and acceptable research study. Such training should include the ethical principles and guidelines that encompass all parts of research from research topic through the literature review to the design and truthful reporting of results. MANAGING SAFETY AND HEALTH IN SCHOOL SERVICE DELIVERY AT THE EARLY CHILDHOOD AND PRIMARY LEVELS OF EDUCATION IN NIGERIA IN THE 21ST CENTURY  BY  PROFESSOR OBIANUJU OSITA OKU FACULTY OF EDUCATION  IMO STATE UNIVERSITY  OWERRI  Introduction 	Provision of adequate safety and health in schools have been rapid and widespread in recent years  and nearly all schools now give an appropriately high priority to getting their safety and health procedures right especially in developed countries. Addressing the issue of management of safety and health in Nigerian schools is quite germane giving the growing incidence of violence across Nigerian schools at all levels and the resultant destruction of lives and property. The chronicle of violent attacks on educational institutions has become a major setback to achieving Nigerian educational goals. In March 2012  12 public schools across Maiduguri were burnt  about 10  000 pupils forced out of school.  In Baga Community Secondary School in Borno state  more than 29 students and a teacher were killed as a result of attack by gunmen in 2013. In the same year about 45 students and some staff of government secondary school in Manudo  Yobe state were killed after insurgents attacked the school. Over 800 classrooms in Yobe state were destroyed leading to the closure of all schools across the state (Odunze  2013). The popular story of the missing Chibok girls where two hundred and seventy six girls were abducted from their school  Government Girls secondary school in Chibok town  Borno state in 2014 is not just a sad commentary on the Nigerian state but also puts a big question on the safety of Nigerian school children. 	The several terror-related incidence in the North East Nigeria  cultism and kidnapping related issues in the south especially south east and south-south Nigeria have instilled justifiable fears on parents on the safety of their children. They are now more concerned about the safety of their children than sending them to school. This  no doubt increased the number of school drop-outs significantly and no doubt must have swelled the Federal Ministry of Education 2010 report of 20 million Nigeria children of pre-school age being out of school  while 10.5 million children were out of primary school. Official statistics from the website of out-of-school children initiative  a partner organization  with UNICEF shows that Nigeria  alone accounts for about 8.7% of 58 million children of primary education that are out of school across the world which is rated as the highest. Researchers  have identified  several factors that may affect school enrolment  retention and learning to infrastructural gap  physical accessibility  sterility  of classroom  violence  hygiene  facilities and practice  recreational facilities   poverty  child labour  school management  among others (Nwogu 2010  Asoelike and Abraham 2011). 	A close look at the identified factors  indicate that they are safety and health related issues and is a pointer to the need for adequate implementation of existing universally established School Health Programme (SHP) and the local  ones such as the Safe School Initiative Programme. This paper is therefore an attempt to examine the issues of Managing Safety and Health for School Service Delivery in the 21st Century.  In specific terms  the paper will be handled under the following headings: â€¢	The concept  of safety and health in relation to school  â€¢	Historical overview of safety and health in Nigeria education  the national picture  â€¢	Key features of outstanding practices at the early childhood and primary schools levels. â€¢	The leadership and management of safety and health at the early childhood and primary levels of education in Nigeria. â€¢	Conclusion  The concept of safety and health in relation to school  Safety refers to the state of being safe from danger or harm. Similarly  health according to World Health Organization (WHO) is a state of complete  physical  mental and social well-being not merely absence of disease or infirmity. When used in relation to schools  it refers to the provision of adequate protection and right type of environment that will guarantee effective teaching and learning. It may be seen as series of harmonized projects and activities in the school environment for the promotion of the health of the learners and teachers and development of the school community. School health is as much as about pupils emotional and mental health as it was about their physical well-being. The United Nations convention on the rights of the child states that as well as in education every child has the right to be safe.  This is a call to education stakeholders to provide a healthy physical and psychological environment to ensure the safety of learners at all levels especially at the early childhood and primary levels. Early childhood education (ECE) is the overall development of the child socially  physically and intellectually. It is therefore conceptualized as encompassing the care  development and education of children below the age of six years. It is the foundation for a lifelong learning (Maduewsi  2008). The rapid mental and physical development that characterize the first six years of life demands that adequate attention should be giving to early childhood development and care. ECE is giving in Nursery and kindergarten schools in Nigeria. The proprietorship of ECE schools are mostly individuals and religious bodies under the control of the Ministry of education who formulate and ensure the implementation of policy guidelines. The same applies to primary education which is a reference to education given to children from age 6-12. Both ECE and primary education are included as part of Basic Education in Nigeria as stated in the UBE Act 2004; the inclusion of ECE in Basic education is an outcome of the realization that learning begins at birth. This has provided supportive policy implications at different sectors including Health and Social services. One of such policy is the National school Health Policy formulated during the Obasanjo regime. The Policy according to Dr. Oby Ezekwesili the then Minister of Education is â€œaimed at promoting the health  of learners to achieve the goals of Education For All (EFA)  and  outline roles of relevant line ministries like  Education  Health  Environment  Water Resources  Information and other stakeholdersâ€  Linkage between EFA  FRESH  Health-Promoting School (HPS)  Child-Friendly School (CFS)  Skill-Based Health Education (SBHE) and Life Skills (LS)                     WHO 2001. Skill for Health: Information series on school health document 9 cited in (National School Health Policy 2006)  The National School Health Policy (NSHP) is primarily basic education focused. The existence of such policy guideline is a right step in a right direction but the worry remains on how effectively the stakeholders have been able to implement the guidelines outlined in it. Can our schools be said to be health promoting schools?  A health promoting school is one that is constantly strengthening its capacity as a healthy setting for living  learning and working. Such schools foster healthy learning environment (WHO 2001). The characteristics of such schools include: â€¢	Location of schools away from potential environmental hazards. â€¢	Protection of the school community from excessive noise  heat  cold and dampness â€¢	Provision of adequate buildings  constructed in line with approved standards  with particular emphasis on facilities for physically challenged learners â€¢	Provision of an appropriate and adequate amount of furniture for learners and staff â€¢	Provision of an adequate number of gender-sensitive toilet facilities â€¢	Provision of adequate safe water supply and sanitation facilities for the school community â€¢	Provision of proper drainage and waste disposal facilities â€¢	Provision of safe recreational and sport facilities â€¢	Perimeter fencing of the school â€¢	Observation of Annual School Health Days â€¢	Promotion of healthy human relationships in the school community â€¢	Promotion of health related-school policies â€¢	Promotion of a maintenance culture	(National School Health Policy  2006)  What is the state of school health in Nigeria?  The first attempt towards introducing school health in Nigeria was made in 1929 in form of introducing a medical services that could cater for school children (Odutan  1972). Giving a historical background of Nigeriaâ€™s attempt at establishing School Health Policy (SHP)  Akani  Nkangineme & Orumabo (2001) narrated that a scheme was proposed that entrusted school inspection to medical officers with special training in that field  and a thrice-a-year examination of school children throughout their school years. In 1944  the Christian Council of Nigeria called attention to the high incidence of malnutrition among school children and hoped that government would inaugurate the proposed school medical service. In 1952  the government of western Nigeria published a policy white paper that contained a four-year plan to introduce a school medical service which would be available and free to all children. The objectives of this policy were to ensure that all school children received regular medical examinations  bring teaching of health into childrenâ€™s homes and also provide a liaison between the homes and medical authorities. In 1971  a school health service headed by a medical officer and assisted by other professional heads emerged at the Federal Government level in Lagos. Special clinics were set up to serve as treatments  points for school children with minor ailments  in some state capital  and large town such as Ibadan  Enugu  Kaduna  Benin City  Zaria and Jos.  	In Rivers state  a school health service unit was established in 1975 with operational base at Diobu Health Centre; it was manned by public health sisters with occasional input from physicians. The activities centered on occasional school inspection and health talks. The situation was so bad t

column35: Professor Simeon Chituru Achinewhu is a distinguished Food and Nutritional Biochemist  a Fellow of the Nigerian Institute of Food Science and Technology  a management Fellow of the International Institute of Leadership and Governance (INILAG) and Fellow of the International Academic of Food Science and Technology FIAFAST). He is a scholar with International recognition having been awarded two prestigious post doctorate Fellowships of the Association of Commonwealth Universities and the Senior Scholar Fulbright Fellowship for which he was a Visiting Commonwealth Fellow at the University of Leeds and a Visiting Fulbright Fellow at the University Massachusetts. He was also a Visiting Post-Doctorate Fellow at the University of Reading. He was Director  Rivers Institute of Agricultural Research and Training  Dean Faculty of Agriculture  Head Department of Food Science and Technology  Dean Post Graduate School and Vice Chancellor 2006 to 2007 of the Rivers State University of Science and Technology. He appointed Resident National Electoral Commissioner for Adamawa State in 1993  was one time Chairman Academic Staff Union of Universities (ASUU) RSUST Branch and a Director PABOD Food Company Rivers State. column35: Professor Francis Kehinde EMENI Ph.D FCA Francis is a Chartered Accountant  and Professor of Accounting  in the Department of Accounting  University of Benin. He is also a Research Fellow with The Institute of Chartered Accountants of Nigeria  Lagos . He holds two Ph.D degrees - in Accounting and in Finance. He also holds membership of his professional bodies - The Institute of Chartered Accountants of Nigeria (ICAN) and The Academy of Management Nigeria (TAMN). He has taught at both undergraduate and post graduate levels and supervising numerous undergraduate and post-graduate projects and theses at the University of Benin and Covenant University where he did his sabbatical. He was recognized as the â€œBest Lecturerâ€ in the Faculty of Management Sciences by University of Benin in the 2011/2012 academic session. Francis is well published. He has authored schorlarly books and articles. His administrative experience is very robust at the faculty  departmental and university levels. He had at various times been the Assistant Dean of the Faculty of Management Sciences  member of Boards of Journals and Monitoring officer Centre for Part-Time Programme in the University of Benin. He is the Founder/President Light of Christ Motherless Babies Home.

column35: SUMMARY OF MY CURRICULUM VITAE  I am Prof. AMBE JOSE PWAVIMBO. Born in the year 1958  16th February. From Adamawa state  Numan Local government of Nigeria. Present place of work is the department of Paediatrics  University of Maiduguri Teaching Hospital  Maiduguri  Borno state. Attended Baptist primary Gombe and preceded to st Johnâ€™s College Kaduna now Rimi College from there went to North East College of Arts and Science (NECAS)  which was later transformed to University of Maiduguri. I graduated from University of Maiduguri in the year 1983  with MBBS degree. Had my NYSC in Bauchi Specialist Hospital. Went for post graduate degree programme inUCH Ibadan. I am a Fellow of the Faculty of Paediatrics of National Post graduate Medical College of Nigeria (May1994). Has over 20 years of teaching and research experience. I am been involved in community and hospital based research in the North-eastern zone of Nigeria. I am a Professor of Paediatric Haematology and Oncology in the University of Maiduguri (2007) and Consultant Paediatrician in the teaching Hospital.  I have worked with NPI / WHO as NIDs consultant for five years from 1998 to 2002. A National coordinator / facilitator in integrated management of childhood illnesses (IMCI)  PMTCT; Roll back malaria case management (RBM)  Infant feeding option in HIV positive mother. I have participated in various workshops in and outside the country in collaboration with the Federal Ministry of Health  UNICEF  WHO and the University of Maiduguri Teaching Hospital. I am still participating in training of trainers in IMCI  malarial control programmes and case managements Was an external examiner to ABU Medical Students from 2004 -2005 and 2009  external examiner to UNIBEN Medical students 2011. I am an examiner to the National Postgraduate Medical College in Part I and II. Was also Head of department from 1996 â€“ 1998  and 2008 to 2010. During that period as Head of Department I have had the opportunity to closely relate with the academic  medical and non-medical staff. This opportunity has helped me to sharpen my human relationships skill as well as my administrative ability. I was also a member of the hospital medical advisory committee (MAC) when it was active during the period. I gained useful insight with the running of a teaching hospital. I have been  involved in publications (50 publications in referenced journals and 2 chapters in 2 books) in various fields such as haematological conditions  neonatology  oncology  and vaccine preventable childhood illnesses. I did one year sabbatical and six months extension in Federal Medical center  as a Consultant Paediatrician  from 2011 to 2012  came back again to FMC  Yola  in June 2013 to 2014 as a consultant Paediatrician. I am the Principal Investigator for clinical drug trial in RBM programme by FMOH â€“ Yobe state  now (2013) Principal Investigator for clinical drug trial in RBM programme   Adamawa state. I have established the Drug Therapeutic efficacy trial sentinel site in Numan  Adamawa State. I am also involved in the state malarial control programmes and pharmacovigilance. Also a member of the national task team on PMTCT 2008 to date. I am involved in accreditation and re-accreditation visits to various tertiary health institutions for postgraduate medical training in the department of Paediatrics. I am also involved in antimalarial drugs research in Numan  Adamawa State.  Re elected HOD  paediatrics  college of medical sciences  University of Maiduguri. Involved in establishing inpatient therapeutic feeding centre for severely malnourished children (ITFC) in UMTH  in partnership with the Alliance for international medical action (ALIMA)   UNICEF and WHO in June 2017.

column35: Owolabi Olumide is a Professor of Computer Science in the Faculty of Science  University of Abuja. He holds a PhD from the University of Strathclyde  Glasgow (1989). He was Associate Dean of Science (2002-2004)  University of Port Harcourt  and has been the ICT Director  University of Abuja since 2006. He is a member of the Nigeria Computer Society and the Computer Professional Registration Council of Nigeria. His current research is on Machine Learning  Computational Intelligence and Health Informatics. He has successfully supervised 3 PhDs. His email address is olumide.owolabi@uniabuja.edu.ng. His telephone number is +2348056143993.

column35: Adebolu  Tinuola Tokunbo is a Professor of Microbiology in the School of Sciences  Federal University of Technology  Akure  Nigeria. She holds a PhD from Obafemi Awolowo University  Ile-Ife (1993). She was Coordinator  Microbiology/Virology Option  ISLT  FUTA (1998-2002); HOD  Microbiology (2012-2015) and Director  Centre for Gender Issues in Science and Technology  FUTA (2017 to date). She is an AWARD mentor (2017). Her current research is Mechanisms of Immunity and the search for non-conventional therapies against bacterial diarrhoea  the second leading cause of death in children under five years. She has successfully supervised 4 PhDs. Her email address is ttadebolu@futa.edu.ng. and her GSM number is +2348053617571.

column35: Sulaiman  Aliyu Kantudu is a Professor of Accounting in the Faculty of Management Sciences  Bayero University  Kano. He holds a PhD from Ahmadu Bello University  Zaria (2006). column33: The Nucleus                                                 Vol.28 (1&2) 63-68 1985  Genotoxicity Of Low Level 60co Radiation: Greater Sensitivity Of Mitochondrial DNAs Of Neurospara Crassa  R.I.B EBANA*AND S.K DUTTA Department of Botany and Radiography  Howard University  Washington DC20059  USA and Department of Biological Sciences  University of Calabar  Calabar  Nigeria.  Received on January 30  1985.    Abstracts  The knowledge regarding the effect of  63CO gamma radiation on the integrity  of DNA structure is essential for radio therapeutic treatment for cancer. Studies on the profiles of the post-irradiation thermal melting curves of the eukaryotic N. crassa DNA showed that N. Crassa DNA  was very sensitive to radiation even at low dosage. A dose â€“ dependent increase in optical density at 260 mn after exposing a DNA sample when compared to thermal denaturation  curves of control or unirridiated DNA was found. The low GC components  (30 percent of  total DNA) of  N. Crassa DNA  which is primarily  mitochondrial DNA  were found to be  more sensitive than the high G+C major(70 percent) fraction consisting primarily of chromosomal  DNA. Results obtained indicate that DNAs from cell organelles  like  those of mitocohodrial DNAs  were more sensitive to 60CO irradiation.     ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS  The advice and suggestion of Dr. Johnson Chopalla ( formerly of the Department of Radiotherapy  Howard University  are gratefully acknowledged and  the  entire staff of the Department of Howard University  Teaching Hospital for providing technical  assistance and making  the  60cobalt  machine  available   and  in particular   Mr.Rao Nibhanupudy who determined  the dosage of radiation used. These research  was  supported in part by grants received from the US Department of Energy  and by an  institutional grant from the U.S. National Institutes  of Health.   REFERENCES  Alexander P. and Bacap  M. (1966) Fundamental of Radiobiology New York Pergamon  Press.  Bridges  BA. Ashword Smith MJ. Microbiological exploitation of cardiac glycosides and alkaloids from garcinia kola  Borreria ocymoides  Kola nitida and Citrus aurantifolia    R.U.B. Ebana  B.C. Madunagu  E.D. Ekpe and I. N. Otung department of Biological sciences University of Calabar  Cross River State  Nigeria.   3539/11/90: accepted 23 March 1991.     Abstracts  The four medicinal plants  Garcinia kola (roots)  Borreria ocymoides (leaves)  Kola nitida (bark) and Citrus aurantrfolia (roots) were screened for phytochemical components. They were found to contain tannins  phlobatannins  polyphenols  hydroxymethyl anthraquinones  glucides  saponins  alkaloids  cardiac glycosides  flavanoids and reducing compounds. The aqueous and alcoholic extracts as well as alkaloids and cardiac glycosides of the medicinal plants were tested on various pathogenic bacteria. They were found to inhibit such organisms as Staphylococcus aureus  Klebsiella pneumoniae  Proteus mirabilis  Pseudomonas aeruginosa  ÃŸ-haemolytic streptococci  Escherichia coli and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The usefulness of the phytochemical bases of these plants as potential sources of pharmaceutical drug preparation is discussed.      ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS  We are grateful to the University of Calabar for the award of research grants  and Mr U.A. Inyang (herbalist) who supplied the medicinal plants. The Nucleus                                                 Vol.28 {1&2) 63-68 1985  GENOTOXICITY OF LOW LEVEL 60CO RADIATION: GREATER SENSITIVITY OF MITOCHONDRIAL DNAS OF NEUROSPARA CRASSA  R.I.B EBANA* AND SK DUTTA Department of Botany and Radiography  Howard University  Washington DC20059  USA and Department of Biological Sciences  University of Calabar  Calabar  Nigeria . Received on January 30  1985.    Abstracts  The knowledge regarding the effect of  63CO gamma radiation on the integrity  of DNA structure is essential for radio therapeutic treatment for cancer . Studies on the profiles of the post-irradiation thermal melting curves of the eurkaryotic N. Crassa DNA was found. The low GC components  (30 percent of  total DNA) of  N. Crassa DNA  which is primarily  mitochondrial DNA  were found to be  more sensitive than the high G+C major(70 percent) fraction consisting primarily of chromosomal  DNA Results obtained indicate that DNAs from cell organelles  like  those of mitocohodrial DNAs  were more sensitive to 63CO irradiation.     ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS  The advice and suggestion of Dr. Johnson Chopalla ( formerly of the Department of Radiotherapy  Howard University  are gratefully acknowledged and  the  entire staff of the Department of Howard University  Teaching Hospital for providing technical  assistance and making  the  60cobalt  machine  available   and  in particular   Mr.Rao Nibhanupudy who determined  the dosage of radiation used. These research  was  supported in part by grants received from the US Department of Energy  and by an  institutional grant from the U.S. National Institutes  of Health. NUTRITIONAL AND POTENTIALLY MEDICINAL VALUES OF THE LEAVES OF LASSIANTHERA AFRICANAN (BEAUV) R.U.B. Ebana*   A.I. ESSIEN**  O.D. Ekpa*** *Department of Biological Sciences  University of Calabar  Calabar  Nigeria . **Department of Animal Sciences  University of Calabar  Calabar  Nigeria . ***Department of Chemistry  Sciences  University of Calabar  Calabar  Nigeria .       Abstracts The potentially medicinal and nutritional  value of the leaves of Lassianthera Africana (Beauv) were investigated. The phytochemicals screening of the leaves revealed  the presence of tannins  anthracquinones  glycosides and reducing compounds .the crude aqueous and alcoholic extracts  a of the leaves were found to inhibit  number of microorganisms except micrococcus sp and Brucella abortus. Antifungal activity of the dry leaf extracts was observed. Chemical analyses showed  the leaves to contain 28.1% dry matter and on dry matter basis 15.7%  crude protein7.6% either extract 15.7%  Crude fibre 15.4% ash and 42.8% nitrogen  Hydrocyanic acid  oxalate  tannin an phytate contents were 6.4 17.1 466.3 2.6mg/100g matter respectively. The leave also constituted  a rich source of mineral elements(100g dry matter):sodium(1860) potassium (2303) calcium(888) phosphorus (490) manganese (218)iron(4.2) and zinc(1.6). She has successfully supervised 12 M.Scs.Her email address is delphinedavtsu@yahoo.com. Her  telephone number is +2347066267678.

column35: Odoh Adejo is a Professor of Local Government and Development Studies  in the Faculty of Administration  Ahmadu Bello University  Zaria. He holds a PhD from Ahmadu Bello University Zaria (1989). He was Head of Department (2001 - 2005). He is a member of the Chattered Institute of Administration. His current research is on The Image of Local Government in Nigeria. He has successfully supervised 18 PhDs. His email address is adejooo@yahoo.com. His telephone number is +2348034050169

column34: Aeronautics and Astronautics in Nigeria: The New Paradigm in Space Exploration and Development
column35: Leo DANIEL is named 2008/09 Dr. Martin Luther King  Jr. Professor of Aeronautics and Astronautics at MIT. He received his MSc (1990) with Highest Honors in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering from Soviet Academy of Science  Donetsk State Technical University and Ph.D. (2000) from University of London  Queen Mary and Imperial College (sponsored by UK MOD & EPSRC)  where he conducted his research. Professor Daniel is an elected Fellow of the Royal Aeronautical Society  a Fellow of Institute of Materials  and Associate Fellow of the American Institute Aeronautics and Astronautics (AIAA). He was a Research Scientist of the UK Defense Evaluation Research Agency from 1996 to 2000  where he led research in the areas of intelligent unmanned aerial vehicle  structural optimization  control structure integrated design  and reusable launch vehicle  composite crashworthiness for military aircraft  the latter of which he was a pioneer in the late nineties. He led efforts at CNRS (Dijon  France) for the development of novel technologies for revolutionary use of YAG laser ultrasonic for detection of mechanical breakdown of nuclear coated-substrate interface in nanoscale in 2001  for which he received an award. In 2002  he joined the European Space Agency (Netherland) as a Senior Research Scientist  where he successfully integrated the use of composite structures in primary structures of a reusable launch vehicle; he led in a design and delivery of flight modules of a European SOCRATES launch vehicle.  As Project Manager at Cranfield University and Airbus UK  he led a successful cost evaluation of Hydraulic Power Systems of Airbus aircraft modules including the A380 series (2004). He joined the Department of Mechanical Engineering of the University of California as a Visiting Professor in 2005. Professor Daniel is currently teaching and conducting research in the areas of aerospace defense  structural dynamics  and hypervelocity impact of composites  nanomaterials  bio-inspired and intelligent structures with applications to morphing aircraft structures  intelligent unmanned area vehicle (IUAV)  bio/medical sensing  intelligent vehicle and highway systems (IVHS). Past work on composites includes the discovery of a â€œbefore unobserved type of impact damage due to composite shell material/structural interactions.â€ Professor Daniel is a recipient of a UK Engineering and Physical Science Research Council (EPSRC) Fellow award and a European Training and Mobility in Research (TMR) award.  Leo has published extensively in top-quality peer-reviewed journals and conference proceedings; and has made numerous presentations at national and international scientific meetings. He served as Track Chair of American Institute Aeronautics and Astronautics Program Committee for Space Transportation. He is the Chair of the Conference and Publications Sub Committee of AIAA Space Transportation Technical Committee. He is an Associate Editor of Book Committee of AIAA Materials TC. He serves as a reviewer for the journals of Spacecraft & Rockets  Part G  Journal of Aerospace  Composites Part B and Composites Science and Technology. He serves as a member of the Scientific Study Section of Institute of Materials - A Scientific Study Committee of the Science Council  Member-at-Large of the Committee of the British Composites Society  and the Nominating and Membership Committee of the Royal Aeronautic Society  Institute of Materials and AIAA. He serves as a member of editorial board of Journal of Metallurgy. He serves as a member of AIAA Academic Affairs Committee  Materials  Space Transportation TCs and International Aeronautical Forum (IAF) Space Transportation Committee.

column35: Noma  Samaila Sani a Professor of Soil Science was born on 14th April  1963 in Rafin Zuru District of Zuru Local Government  Kebbi State. He studied at Dongo Primary School  Zuru (1977-1980)  Dantudu Gomo Primary School  Zuru (1980-1982)  Government Day Sec. School  Zuru (1982-1985)  Govt. Science Sec. School  Zuru (1985-1987)  Usmanu  Danfodiyo University  Sokoto (1988-1994)  University of Ibadan (1997-1998) and Usmanu  Danfodiyo University  Sokoto (2001-2005). He joined the services of Usmanu Danfodiyo University in 1995 as Assistant Lecturer and became a Professor of Soil Science in 2012.  Professor S.S. Noma has served as Acting Head  Department of Soil Science  UDUS  2004 to Nov. 2007.  Department of Soil Science  Kebbi State University of Science and Technology (2008-2009)  Faculty Exams Officer  February (2009 to April  2011). Chairman  Thesis and dissertation Review/Vetting Committee (2010 to 2014). Departmental PG. Coordinator  January (2014 to 2015).  Faculty PG Coordinator  September (2014 to October  2016).  Professor S.S. Noma is a serving Editor-in-Chief  Journal of Agric. and Environment  Oct. 2014 to Date.  Editor-in-Chief  ASUU Journal of Science September  2015 to Date.  He has also served as Deputy Dean Postgraduate School  November (2016 to June  2017) and was later appointed as Dean  on 27th June  2017.  Professor S.S. Noma has served as External Examiner at College of Agriculture  Zuru   College of Agriculture and Animal Health Bakura  Bayero University  Kano  Ahmadu Bello University  Zaria at different times. He has also served many communities near and far at various capacities.  Professor S.S. Noma served as chairman  Students Disciplinary Committee during his one year Sabbatical period at Federal University  Dutsin-Ma (November  2015 â€“September  2016) and many other committees in the university within the Sabbatical period. Professor S.S. Noma has supervised many B.Sc. projects  M.Sc. dissertations and Four (4) Ph.D. theses in diverse fields as Soil Science  Applied Chemistry  Crop Science  Forestry  Botany and Geography. He has over 65 publications in national and international journals besides been co-author to two books. Professor S.S. Noma has served as member and sometimes chairman of many University Statutory and Ad-hoc committees such as Deputy Chairman Examinations Monitoring Committee (April  2014 â€“ June  2015)  Chairman Examinations Monitoring Committee (June  2015 â€“September  2016) among others. His telephone number is 07037777273

column33: 1) EFFECT OF CHRONIC ORAL ADMINISTRATION OF CHLOROQUINE ON THE HISTOLOGY OF THE LIVER IN WISTAR RATS. A. IZUNYA  A.O. NWAOPARA  L.C. ANYANWU  M.A.C. ODIKE  G.A. OAIKHENA  J.K. BANKOLE AND O. OKHAI. PUBLISHED IN BRITISH JOURNAL OF PHARMACOLOGY AND TOXICOLOGY. ISSN (2010) MAXWELL SCIENTIFIC ORGANIZATION. ABSTRACT: The effect of oral administration of chloroquine  an antimalarial and antirheumatic drug on the histology of the liver on wistar rats was investigated. the treated group rats were administered 20 mg/kg body wt  weekly of chloroquine for 4 weeks while the control group rats were given distilled water for 4 weeks. on day 29 of the experiment  the rats were weighed and sacrificed by cervical dislocation. The livers were carefully dissected out and quickly fixed in 10% formal saline for histological studies. The histological findings after H and E methods indicated that the treated sections of the liver showed cytoplasmic vacuolation; nuclear enlargement and vesiculation of the hepatocytes when compared with the control. Thus  our result suggests that though chloroquine may be a widely used antimalarial and antirheumatic drug  its chronic administration may have a deleterious effect on the liver of wistar rats and by extension may affect its function. it Is therefore recommended that the drug be prescribed with caution in patients with history of liver disease.  2) RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN NECK CIRCUMFERENCE  WAIST CIRCUMFERENCE  BODY MASS INDEX  ARM CIRCUMFERENCE AND WAIST HIP RATIO AS PREDICTORS OF CADIOVASCULAR RISK FACTORS. R.E. UCHEYA  S.E. OKONOFUA  L.C. ANYANWU AND J.C. IGWEH. BIOSCIENCES  BIOTECHNOLOGY RESEARCH ASIA. VOL. 6(1)  87-100 (2009) ABSTRACT: Neck circumference (NC) as an upper body obesity index  is a simple screening measure for identifying overweight and obese patients. Based on the clinical significance of body mass index (BMI)  waist circumference (WC)  hip circumference (HC) and waist hip ratio (WHR)  this study examines a relationship between BMI  WC  WHR and NC. In a random sample cohort study the study group was comprised of 218 subjects (Male) with no known major medical conditions who were not receiving any medication therapy. With age (17-34) divided into two age groups (17-25 and 26-34) with mean values (77.06 Â± 0.56 and 82.97 Â± 1.5 respectively) showed a significant difference (P â‰¤0.05). Main indicators studied included NC  WC  WHR and BMI. Pearson's correlation coefficients indicated a significant association between changes in WC and changes in NC (r= 0.46 each  P â‰¤ 0.001) BMI and NC  (r=0.51 each  P â‰¤ 0.0001) Age and NC ( r= 127 each  P â‰¤0.05) but was insignificant for WHR and NC  (r=0.1  each P â‰¤ 0.07). Changes in WC  BMI  and age correlated positively with changes in NC but negatively with changes in WHR and the NC was revealed to be double the WC. This might be used as a reliable  simple  quick  and cheap method for predicting cardiovascular risk factors for coronary heart diseases and can possibly provide a very useful criterion for fashion designers for predicting waist circumference if a simple measurement of neck circumference is employed.  3) THE HEPATOPRODUCTIVE EFFECT OF VITAMIN C AND E ON HEPATOTOXICITY INDUCED BY ETHANOL IN SPRAGUE DAWLEY RATS. C.A. OYINBO  W.N. DARE  G.R.A. OKOGUN  L.C. ANYANWU  N.M. IBEABUCHI  C.C. NORONHA AND O.A. OKANLAWON. PAKINSTAN JOURNAL OF NUTRITION 5(6): 507-511  2006 ISSN 1680-5194 ASIAN NETWORK FOR SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION  2006. ABSTRACT: Ethanol Liver Disease is a major health problem worldwide. One aspect of ethanol toxicity that has received increasing attention in recent years is the role of free radical species in the etiology of liver injury. Vitamins C and E  are antioxidants that scavenge for free radicals. the effect of 200mg Vitamin C + 200mg Vitamin E as food supplement administered for 7 days was studied on hepatic damage induced by ethanol (40% v/v  2.0mg/ 100g body weight per oral for 21 days) in male Sprague-Dawley rats. The supplements were also administered for the last week of 21 days administration of ethanol. Serum transaminases  Lipid peroxidase and Bilrubin were estimated to acess liver damage. Our results showed that ethanol induce increased serum Transaminases  Lipid peroxidase and Bilrubin levels. The biochemical findings were supplemented by histopathological examination of the liver sections. The study confirmed the hepatoprotective effects of Vitamin C and E on the hepatocytes of rats as demonstrated by previous investigators.

column33: 1. About 65% of cancer deaths globally occur in low to middle income countries (LMICs) where prioritization and allocation of resources to cancer care are often quite poor. In the absence of governmental focus on this problem  this study was able to show that In LMICs  effective partnership between public and private institutions can lead to tangible strides in cancer control.   Chukwumere E.Nwogu  Martin Mahoney  Ifeoma Okoye  Kenneth Ejiogu  Saby George  GraceDy  Mutiu Jimoh  Omolola Salako  Oge Ilegbune  Bindiya Chugani  Emmanuel Ezeome  AbiodunO.Popoola  and Arthur M.Michalek. Role of Private Enterprise in Cancer Control in Low to Middle Income Countries. Journal of Cancer Epidemiology Volume 2016  Article ID 7121527  5 pages http://dx.doi.org/10.1155/2016/7121527  2. A descriptive retrospective analysis of â€˜screening/diagnostic mammographicâ€™ breast density pattern among Females seen over a four-year period  2007- 2010  at the Radiodiagnosis department of the University of Nigeria Teaching Hospital (UNTH)  Enugu in South-East Nigeria was reviewed. The study found that a significant proportion of women  50 years and above still retain â€˜risk-conferringâ€™ high mammographic density pattern.    Okere PCN  Aderibigbe ASO  Iloanusi NI  Itanyi DU  Okoye IJ. Mammographic Density Pattern in     Enugu  South-East Nigeria: An audit and review of literature. WAJR 2010:17 (1) pp18-23.  3. The stimulus for this study was the impending cancer epidemic in Africa. In Nigeria  this disease was found to be causing untold devastation  defining an imperative need to institute control measures. Breast  cervical  prostate  and liver cancers were found to be the most common types in Nigerian adults. In children  the predominant malignant disease was Burkitt's. C. E. Nwogu   E. R. Ezeome    M. Mahoney   I Okoye   A. M. Michalek. Regional Cancer Control in South-Eastern Nigeria: A Proposal Emanating from a UICC-sponsored Workshop. WEST AFRICAN JOURNAL OF MEDICINE. column51: the Nigerian State has consistently held the view that the problem in the Niger-Delta is the criminal activities of the people in the region.  For example

The President saw everybody in the State as criminal including members of Bayelsa State Government and the Governor of the State.  This presupposes that the Nigerian State epitomized by the President and Commander-In-Chief of the Armed Forces saw the people of Niger-Delta as criminals without bordering to understand their predicaments.  (ii)	On the other hand
column55: the position of the transnational oil companies is that the problem in the Niger-Delta is the attitude of the local communities to oil exploitation in their areas.  For example

(iii)	The governments of leading western countries tend to see the problem in much the same way that the Nigerian State and the oil companies view the problem in the Niger-Delta.  While they recognize that issues of development may be involved

column78: the problems of the Niger-Delta are not only multi-dimensional

column81: the following problems are identified: (1)	Since the commencement of oil exploration and exploitation in 1956 at Oloibiri
column82: the Niger-Delta Region has not benefited much from the revenues generated

column106: the inhabitants of their host communities have been subjected to extreme poverty and penury. (4)	The laws put in place by the Federal Government of Nigeria for the exploitation of oil and gas resources in the Niger-Delta by the transnational oil companies did not take the host communities into consideration
column108: been flagrantly abused by the oil companies over the years. (5)	The region has become environmentally degraded through oil spillages

column114: and carbon dioxide emissions in the area are among the highest in the world.  It has been calculated that some 45.8 billion kilowatts of heat are discharged into the atmosphere of the region from flaring
column115: 1.8 billion cubic feet of gas every day (Agbola and Olurin

(8)	Community leaders who opposed the policies and activities of both the government and the transnational oil companies are often arrested and detained

column135: 2003:25-28)   Review of Related Literature on Niger -Delta Region Nigeria is the worldâ€™s 13th largest oil producer
column136: and the 6th largest in OPEC. In the domestic sector
column138: oil generated almost $231 billion for the Nigerian economy
column139: constituting between 21 and 48 percent of GDP. Nigeria has an estimated oil reserve of 32 billion barrels â€“ sufficient for 37 years at the current rate of production (Heymans and Pycroft
column140: 2003). Oil dominates the Nigerian economy. Between 2000 and 2004
column141: oil accounted for around 79.5% of total government revenues and around 97% of foreign exchange revenues (UNDP
column142: 2006). This rise in oil wealth has not translated into significant increases in living standards in Nigeria.   In fact
column143: the rise in poverty and inequality coincides with the discovery and export of oil in Nigeria. As (Sala-i-Martin and Subramanian 2003:4) show
column145: when oil revenue was about US$33 per capita
column146: GDP per capita was US$245. In 2000
column147: when oil revenues were US$325 per capita
column148: GDP per capita was stalled at the 1965 level. Evidence such as this has led to widespread acceptance that Nigeria has suffered from the resource curse and according to Sala-i-Martin and Subramanian (2003:24)
column149: waste and poor institutional quality stemming from oil has been primarily responsible for Nigeriaâ€™s poor long-run economic performance. The Niger-Delta region is the area covered by the natural delta of the Niger River and the areas to the east and west. The broader of Niger Delta region consists of nine states (Abia
column156: Ondo and Rivers) and 185 local governments (UNDP
column157: 2006: 44). The estimated regional population is nearly 30 million people. Difficult topography encourages people to gather in small communities. Of the estimated 13
column159: approximately 94% have populations of less than 5000 people (UNDP
column160: 2006: 15). The oil boom in Nigeria has been driven by oil extracted from the Niger Delta region.  Oil wealth
column162: is largely responsible for sustaining the Nigerian Federation (UNDP
column163: 2006: 62). Despite fuelling much of Nigeriaâ€™s economic growth
column164: the Niger Delta is somewhat marginalized from Nigeriaâ€™s national development. Essentially
column165: there is a significant disconnect between the wealth the region generates for the Nigerian Federation and the transnational oil companies extracting oil from the region
column166: and the regionâ€™s human development progress.  Analysis of poverty and human development indicators paints a dismal picture for the Niger Delta.  Poverty incidence increased in the Niger Delta between 1980 and 2004 as shown in Table I below:  Table I: Incidence of Poverty in the Niger-Delta Region - 1980-2004 Country/States	1980	1985	1992	1996	2004 Nigeria	28.1	46.3	42.7	65.6	54.4 Edo/Delta	19.8	52.4	33.9	56.1	Delta 45.35   Edo 33.09 Cross River	10.2	41.9	45.5	66.9	41.61 Imo/Abia	14.4	33.1	49.9	56.2	Imo 27.39 Abia 22.27 Ondo	24.9	47.3	46.6	71.6	42.15 Rivers/Bayelsa	7.2	44.4	43.4	44.3	Rivers   29.09 Bayelsa 19.98 Source: National Bureau of Statistics The regionâ€™s human development index is 0.564 and while this is slightly higher than the Nigerian HDI of 0.448
column167: the area rates far below regions or countries with similar gas or oil reserves (Venezuela is 0.772 and Indonesia is 0.697) (UNDP
column168: 2006: 15).  When further disaggregated to the local government level
column169: the Niger Delta Human Development Report shows that state and regional HDI scores mark inequalities in human development among oil producing communities. Significantly
column170: local government areas without oil facilities appear to have fewer poor people than those with oil facilities (UNDP
column171: 2006: 15). The report also concludes that decline in the HDI has been steeper for the Niger Delta states than the rest of Nigeria (UNDP

column174: driving up prices and so constraining the purchasing power of ordinary people and making it difficult for many to meet the costs of basic needs such as: housing

column179: poverty and inequality in Nigeria has strong regional concentrations
column180: resulting in significant levels of regional disparity.  Table 2 below shows that poverty is considerably higher in the Northern part than the Southern part of Nigeria:           Table 2:    Trends in Poverty Levels by Zones in Nigeria (1980-2004) Zone	1980	1985	1992	1996	2004 South South	13.2	45.7	40.8	58.2	35.1 South East	12.9	30.4	41.0	53.5	26.7 South West	13.4	38.6	43.1	60.9	43.0 North Central	32.2	50.8	46.0	64.7	67.0 North East	35.6	54.9	54.0	70.1	72.2 North West	37.7	52.1	36.5	77.5	71.2 Source: National Bureau of Statistics  It is germane to state that the poverty of the Northern part of Nigeria is more in terms of human development index (HDI) than infrastructural development index (IDI).  On the other hand
column181: the Niger Delta region has better developed human capital through individual self effort
column183: neglected and marginalized by the Federal Government of Nigeria.  The poverty of the North as recognized by the colonial masters led to the amalgamation of the Northern and Southern Protectorates in 1914
column184: as the surpluses from the South was used to net-off the deficit from the Northern part of the country after the amalgamation.   Regrettably
column185: the poverty level of the North had consistently dragged back and prevented the South from developing; especially the Niger Delta region where the major source of revenue to the federation is derived from.  The Niger Delta region today is a place of frustrated expectations and deep-rooted mistrust. Unprecedented restiveness at times erupts in violence. Long years of neglect and conflict have fostered a siege mentality specifically among youths who feel they are condemned to a future without hope and see conflict as a strategy to escape deprivation.  While turmoil in the delta has many sources and motivations
column186: the preeminent underlying cause is the historical failure of governance at all levels. Declining economic performance leading to rising unemployment or underemployment; the lack of access to basic necessities of life like water
column188: food and clothing; discriminatory policies that deny access to positions of authority and prevent people from participating in shaping the rules that govern their lives â€“ these all indicate that governance overtime has fallen short of the peopleâ€™s expectations (Wifa
column189: 2008:3). Many Reports have chronicled the Regionâ€™s monumental problems. The magnitude of the problems of the people of the Niger Delta is best illustrated in the Report by the World Bank in 1995.  In a 1995 two volume study entitled; ""Defining an Environmental Development Strategy for the Niger Delta"" was conducted by the Industry and Energy Operations Division of West Central Africa Department of the World Bank. The region is described in the following words: The Niger Delta has been blessed with an abundance of physical and human resources
column190: including the majority of Nigerianâ€™s oil and gas deposits
column194: as well as a well developed industrial base
column197: and a vibrant private sector. However
column198: the regionâ€™s tremendous potentials for economic growth and sustainable development remains unfulfilled and its future is threatened by deteriorating economic conditions that are not being address by present policies and actions (World Bank
column199: 1995). The Report goes further to lament that: â€¦. Despite its vast reserve
column200: the region remains poor (GNP) per capita is below national average of $280 (World Bank
column201: 1995). The Report continued: Education levels are below the national average and are particularly low for women. While 76 percent of Nigerian children attend primary schools this level drops to 30% in some parts of the Niger Delta. The poverty level in the Niger Delta is exacerbated by the high cost of living. In the urban areas of Rivers State
column202: the cost of living index is the highest in Nigeria (World Bank
column203: 1995).  	  The Federal Government of Nigeria has        	     never been sincere to the Niger-Delta           	                                                                                                 people. Efforts so far made by the Federal Government of Nigeria  to ameliorate the problems of the Niger-Delta Region  	Since Nigeria gained independence in 1960
column204: the Federal Government of Nigeria had made the following impressionistic efforts at ameliorating the problems of the Niger-Delta Region: (1)	The first attempt at addressing the backwardness
column205: poverty and neglect in the Niger-Delta Region from 1956 when oil exploration and exploitation started found expression in the establishment of the Niger-Delta Development Board (NDDB) in 1959 by the Colonial Administration.  Unfortunately
column206: NDDBâ€™s assignment suffered major setback with the onset of the Nigerian Civil War in 1967 as the board became functionally otiosified. (2)	In 1993
column207: the Federal Government of Nigeria established the Oil Mineral Producing Areas Development Commission (OMPADEC) in line with the recommendations of The Belgore Commission.  OMPADEC suffered from lack of planning and collapsed leaving numerous unfinished projects.  Eventually
column208: OMPADEC failed to solve the problems in the Niger-Delta Region
column209: thereby necessitating the need for the Federal Government to return to the drawing table in order to improve the situation (Iyoha
column211: the Federal Government established the Niger Delta Development Commission (NDDC) amidst opposition from activists in the region that the Commission would not be accountable to the communities
column212: and would suffer from mismanagement and corruption.  Some Niger-Delta residents are already criticizing the NDDC
column213: while the Commissionâ€™s staff had been complaining of inadequate funding.  In 2004
column214: NDDC prepared a Draft Master-Plan for the region
column215: which was estimated to cost US$2.9 billion over a fifteen year period.  Unfortunately
column216: Movement for the Emancipation of the Niger Delta (MEND) rejected NDDC and criticized the Commission on the ground that it is: â€œa channel for further looting of the meagre sums of money allocated to the development of the Niger-Delta Regionâ€.  As if (MEND) was prophesizing
column217: Nigerians were recently astonished to hear that the Chairman of the Board gave the sum of 800 million Naira (Nigerian currency)
column218: an equivalent of US$5.1 million to a witch-doctor to assist him consolidate his position as the Chairman of the Board
column219: and one wonders how a paid employee was able to raise such huge sum of money.  From all available information
column220: the effect of NDDC is yet to be felt by the people of the Niger-Delta Region. (4)	In 2009
column221: the Federal Government of Nigeria established the Ministry of Niger Delta to handle the infrastructural development of the region.  So far and unfortunately too
column222: adequate financial allocation has not been made to the Ministry and the implications of this is that the Ministry may fail woefully like its predecessors if adequate fund is not given to it.  In a nutshell
column223: one can categorically infer without fear of contradiction that these agencies  were not really established to bring succour or development to the Niger-Delta Region
column224: but mere impressionistic or cosmetic efforts
column225: because it did not take the same Federal Government of Nigeria long time and effort to develop and transform the Federal Capital
